transport.comment:
It's basically a bicycle, isn't it? On the inside. Mine was and 20mph just didn't cut it. I could *get away* with it most places but the downsides only accumulated, eventually I threw up my hands, sold it, and bought an XM-4000li. Which had its own set of problems. 

Didn't come with a BMS so I had to buy one for it, had a bad cell, needed to replace a bunch of incidental parts like lights over time, wound up replacing all cells after less than 5 years because of drastically different levels of wear. It's reliable *now*, but after all the extra work and money I put into it I may as well have just bought an Enertia or some other modest American two wheeled EV. 

Chinese EVs are an implicit multi-year hobby project you have to take on, just to get them up to the same standard of reliability as something made in the US. :\

transport.comment:
Thanks for the response, and for pulling those numbers out. The title of this post may have been a bit sensational, but the findings of the [2006 NREL study]( http://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy07osti/38304-01.pdf) (PDF) of California homes did show that gain in home sale price for homes with PV installed (albeit in homes in wealthy areas). 

From the linked study, page 331:

*Resale prices for 29 homes analyzed (the first 29 homes sold in the area) show that the increase in value for SheaHomes* (the “zero-energy homes" of the study’s title) *averaged 55.4% and 44.7% for the comparison homes. The mean gain in sales price for SheaHomes was $306,509 over original price. The most expensive home sold for $1.1 million. The mean gain in sales price for the comparison homes was $264,562 over the original price. The most expensive comparison home sold for $995,000.*

Another important thing to point out is, especially in the case of the Colorado study, some of these PV systems had been installed 3-5 years before the homes were sold, meaning that the owners took advantage of rebates and tax credits to lower their first-year costs, and also got to reap the benefits of lower energy bills by selling their power back to the utility at the retail rate (Colorado net metering, heyyy), so with the price premium at the time of sale, they made out pretty well.

transport.comment:
http://imgur.com/NzPgp4d

My DIY electric truck, solar powered.  

It's a stupid idea based on my grasp of the physical world.  Even with 100% efficient solar panels a car isn't a good place to put them.  The energy used to overcome aerodynamic drag at highway speed is enormous. Were talking tens of thousands of watts in my super-efficient Tesla.  You've got a few square meters of surface area at most.  The sun only puts out a certain amount of power. Around 1000w/sq meter at noon.  Any angular misalignment reduces that substantially.

Do you want to drive slow, or drive very infrequently.  Pick one, otherwise your solar car needs to break the rules of physics.

Elon originally planned a solar roof as an option for the tesla.  He decided against it, impractical.  I'd love to watch you argue with elon over the physical possibility of a solar powered car that would make it in the real world.  Crash tests, high speed capability, inconsistency of solar output would all undoubtedly be among his first points.

transport.comment:
I admit. I did sneak in the 'decent' part in that sentence. I can imagine people finding 50kW not good enough for road tripping. When the new charging standards are finished next year, those can be similar (or faster) than the current supercharger standard though.

The whole 'widespread' part does depend a bit, I understand the supercharger network in the US is pretty good compared to CCS/CHAdeMO. Here in Europe it's basically the other way around.

And for the 300+ miles comment, I'm not sure I agree with the 5 minutes requirement. I think 20-30 minutes is okay if you can drive 300 miles on a charge. While you're correct that that's what you'd do with a gasoline car, there are not many people who can (or should) drive for over 3,5 hours without taking a decent 20 minute+ break. So yes, technically you can fill up a car in five minutes, and continue the trip however if you've just driven over 200 miles you really *should* take a break.

transport.comment:
I figured that 120mi range is enough for 99.9% of my driving.  I only drive an average of 10,000mi a year.  Most (if not all) of my charging will be in my garage.  I don’t really go on any road trips, and if I want to, there are other vehicles in my household.

So why would I pick an e-Golf over a Model 3?  First, I have a strong preference for hatchbacks.  Not just “it has a hatch”, but classic hatchback styling.  That’s why I currently drive a Golf R.  Second, I prefer small, compact cars.  That is why I wouldn’t consider a Model S even if I could afford one.  The Model 3 is still longer than my Golf.  Third, the compact hatchback has still been able to transport large objects that I don’t think could even be attempted in a Model 3.  I have had to transport such objects twice in the past couple months, and I recall trying to figure out what to do if they didn’t fit.

That said, I don’t want to give up AWD, and I have read that dual motors actually get better range, which I think is due to better regeneration?

transport.comment:
What are you *talking about*?

The recharge time on a mid-journey, direct current ("Level 3") charger ranges between VERY ROUGHLY 100-250 miles of range added in 30 minutes, depending on car model, charger specifics, and your drive style.

Multi-hour charge times are a characteristic of *destination* chargers - the kind you'd plug your car into before spending hours doing other things (like, say, sleeping).

In a Tesla Model 3, long range, read wheel drive, you're looking at under 30 minutes' charge time total for the whole journey, leaving Boston on a full charge and arriving in DC nearly empty - one stop in Greenwich CT and one in Newark DE.

At the other end, a 2019 Chevy Bolt you're looking at about 90 minutes total charging (due to both the Bolt having a lower charge capability, and the compatible chargers being slower on average) - a top-up in Sturbridge MA, mall in NY, and a gas station near Wilmington DE.

I've done Boston to Bridgeport CT without stopping in the dead of winter (where the cold affects range considerably) in a Bolt.

transport.comment:
My ebike has a 52v 13Ah battery, I run my motor at 1500W, it does 35 easily on flat ground. There are some really steep hills near my house though, and it drops to 15 on those.
Not sure if its the battery or what. Perhaps a 17.5Ah battery would handle it better(less voltage sag), or switching to a mid-drive motor(more torque).

My battery *hates* the cold though. When its warm, I get full speed and quick acceleration(0-30 faster than my car). When its cold, my top speed is about 26, acceleration is slower, voltage sag is really bad.
So I’ve started taking the battery inside at night to charge.

Keeping your tires properly inflated helps a lot. I’ve got WTB Velociraptors on my bike, they’re good up to 65PSI, I keep them around 50. Higher PSI = lower rolling resistance.

transport.comment:
To #1, no there aren't, not really. There are *some* people who need to go 300 miles without stopping, but not a lot. There are probably more people who *think* they do, perhaps, but that's essentially 4-5 hours of straight driving. That's not very common to do regularly, but yes, some people do. Fine. They *shouldn't* get an EV now if time is more important to them than money. I don't care. It's a "low hanging fruit" issue. The last 5-10% are always the hardest to convert to a new and better technology, and frankly EVs will *never* win the range or speed to refuel contests with ICE vehicles, and that's ok. 

As a dumb analogy, smartphones will *never* win the battery life contest with dumb phones. That didn't stop them from grabbing 98% of the phone market, because they're so much better in every other way that we all just stopped caring about the battery life issue and adapted to a phone that needed to be charged daily (or more often!) rather than weekly. The same thing will happen with EVs. Once more people try them and enjoy the performance, the lower cost to fuel, the lower maintenance, and the realization they'll *never* have to sit around a Jiffy Lube for an hour 3-4 times a year *ever again*, they'll put up with the extra two hours that the 500 mile road trip they take one or twice a year will require in return for how much better an EV is in *all* other respects. 

And from an environmental standpoint, that last 5% who refuse to switch aren't going to make a significant difference. There's plenty of low hanging fruit that will convert sooner than they do.

transport.comment:
I did the math and our savings aren't as good as yours unfortunately (this doesn't invalidate your experience not mine).

For me, electricity is 18¢ more or less (including all fees) and gas is around $3/gallon (or less, I live in Texas). Just like you, the car is being driven a lot (at least 300 miles a week for work commute) but the previous car was averaging about 28 mpg.

So, per day, the car is driven about 20% of the battery for those 50 miles (the Bolt EV has a 65 kWh battery), so that's about 13 kWh per day, times six days times 52 weeks for a total of 4,056 kWh at 18¢ (yes, I've looked, nothing better) that's about $730 per year. 

The ICE vehicle had an efficiency of 28 mpg, so, 50 miles per day, times six days times 52, is a total of 15,600 miles, divided by 28 miles per gallon is a total of about 557 gallons, multiplied by $3 is about $1,671 per year. 

So, only in fuel, I'm saving about +$900 per year. Like you, there will be an extra $200 added to registration (due in two years) but the insurance did go up about $100/month, so we're $500 down.

Why did we choose the Bolt EV though? Affordability. Besides the tax credit, we were able to 'haggle' for a bit lower price, so the total amount was lower than most of the other affordable Chevy vehicles. 

Also, something that people completely ignore, is the cost of the charger and installation of that charger. Thankfully GM includes a Level 1/2 charger and a $1k install, but others don't. A reliable EVSE (or...charger for simpler although incorrect term) is about $400 and depending on the type of installation, it could be another $400 at the very least. 

Also, sure, no more $60 oil changes and other annoying maintenance stuff, but, tires will needed to be changed sooner than ICE vehicles. 

By the way, just because I bring both the positives AND negative sides doesn't make me a hater, I just don't want people to be misled and then they become the haters.

transport.comment:
That is why I made the distinction between an EREV and a PHEV. An EREV is primarily a fully-capable electric vehicle with a gasoline engine *only* as a range-extender. The goal is maximum *efficiency.*

If *performance* is the goal, then a PHEV could (as you said) use the traction motor and the ICE in parallel. This is also a method to compensate for a weak hybrid (i.e., small ICE, small motor, small battery) like the Prius Prime.

I have read in other forums where some people have claimed to modify their Chevrolet Volts in software to run the traction motor and the ICE in parallel. They effectively double the power output at the expense of fuel efficiency.

transport.comment:
I think you're thinking scales still too high for it to be an issue.

At the extreme end it becomes used as frequently as motor oil. A store can't possibly make 10 sales a day, they couldn't possibly afford to have fuel pumps. If they didn't have fuel pumps they wouldn't have tanker truck deliveries. Sure gas is still a thing, but it's sold in 5 gallon jerry cans on the shelf, next to the motor oil, because they now have similar sales volume.

And all the nations refineries wouldn't all continue to operate at 10% capacity, they'd shutdown 90% of them. Now you have one refinery serving the entire country. All those pipelines to other refineries shutdown because there isn't someone at the other end.

Also, most pipelines have minimum flow rates, petroleum gels when it gets too cold, and it it stops and cools in the pipe it clogs.  Yea many are shipping refined fuel, but the big long distance ones, like the Alaska pipeline don't.  As you said, the Alaskan pipeline is only doing 25% of the capacity, a quick google says they have a hard floor of about 10% of the design capacity.

Basically, I think a lot of people look at this and say if we only had 40% of the current oil consumption, then just maybe half of the gas stations go out of buisness, and you're probably right, along with a refinery or two shutting down. But when you get to say 90-95% of vehicles on the road being EVs, I think the distribution network starts having trouble maintaining any pumps at all (especially the distribution terminals). At that point, whoever is left ditches their ICE, and it becomes a fuel for your historic vehicles.

housing.comment:
>I would be very interest in an AMA, for instance, 

>What are your typical job tasks in a solar module manufacturing facility? 

Recently my employer closed down nearly 1\2 of their entire process which includes the crystal growing area and the wafer area. I work in the next section of the process which is called cell. We take the wafers and convert them to solar cells which are then sent to the final stage of the process where the individual cells are made into a module. 

For the most part everyone works at what we call "a tool" which is essentially a robot designed to do a specific task in the process. 

First there is a robot that takes the wafers out of the boxes they are shipped in and inserts them into carriers (think of a magazine for a gun) and then also loads them into the TRA which is an overhead series of tracks that run all over the fabrication floor to all the different tools (kind of like an overhead river of carriers) 

Next the carriers loaded with wafers go to a a processes designed to remove and saw damage the wafers may have on them from when they were cut from the ingot. This is a chemical process designed to remove and odd edges and make the texture of the wafers uniform. Essentially this is a cleaning process

Next the carriers go to a plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition process which adds what looks like a golden sheen on the backside of the wafer which is designed to enhance the efficiency of energy conversion.

Next they go to laser tools which etch lines onto the front and back of the wafers which is another step to increase the efficiency.

Next they go through a process which removes any phosphorus glass on the wafers. Another chemical process designed to remove any uneven edges. This is another cleaning process.

Next the go get silicon nitride put on them which also increases efficiency.

Now the wafers have all the chemical processes done to them and they are sent across the hall to the Printline. If you have ever screen printed a T-shirt you already understand this process its essentially the same. The wafer carriers are loaded into the front end of the tool and they are moved under a screen with a thin membrane to allow a silver paste to be printed directly unto the lines the laser tool etched. Then the wafer goes through a dryer and its flipped so silver bus bars are placed on the back side, then through another dryer and then an aluminum paste is added around the bus bars. This process is what allows the electrons to flow through the wafers.

At this point we have completed solar cells.

Next the cells go through a testing/quality control process which tests the efficiency of the cells and then they are sorted by efficiency to be sent to moduling. 

I don't really know the moduling process so I can't really speak to that, I apologize. I've tried many times to get over there and learn it but it seems that my company doesn't want people to know other areas. 

The daily tasks for 98% of employees consist of loading and unloading carriers into the specific tool they work on. Occasionally an alarm will sound signaling an error then the operator will go fix that, usually by just pushing a button.


>What major manufacturer recalls are you aware of? What for?

For the company I work for I know of none. I'm not very happy about how the employees are treated but I am still very proud that we make the highest quality product in the industry. Our motto is "our customers come back, not our products." They have a 30 year guarantee and if for any reason they fail we will fix them or replace them at no cost.

>Have you ever considered going to China and sharing your expertise? You would probably be paid a lot more than what you currently make.

Thought about it but the non disclosure agreements I've signed would prevent me from saying much more then what I've told you. 

>Why aren't we seeing more integrated modules with micro-inverters?

Good question. I have no idea. I know lots of companies are selling "kits" which are kind of like all in one boxes which include modules and inverters in the kit. But that's not interested they're still individual components. 

>What is done to seal the aluminum frame to the module glass?

Again I can't really speak to any level of detail of moduling, I know its essentially like a caulking. 

>What is your long term maintenance concern with solar modules?

If you buy ours, very little. But average maintenance stuff such as, clearing off leaves and needles during fall, cleaning the glass of pollen and oxidation. Just super easy basic stuff. Another company I wanted to work with is a solar array leasing company, they lease you the array, install it, and maintain it for 20 years. 

Sorry for the vagueness of my answers I'm still technically a temp employee I've only worked there for 9 months. Essentially 1\2 way through my 18 month temp contract. Thanks for the questions though, I love talking about this stuff!!

housing.comment:
Alright.  I'm not sure how much to throw at you at once, so I'll just state a thesis: renewable resources alone cannot power the economy we have today, nor will they be able to.  If energy becomes more costly, it will make everything else more costly as well.  If that happens, the level of complexity of our economy must be reduced.  That means, among other things, reduced aid programs, reduced research and development programs, reduced capacity of production (including silly things like pharmaceuticals), and even reduced energy research.  

You might be inclined at this point to challenge my assumption that renewables make energy more expensive.  Hydro is the only renewable energy resource cheaper than fossil fuels, and it has already been built out.  Every other renewable energy resource is more expensive than fossil fuels.  If that were not so, they wouldn't need subsidies.

You might next wish to suggest that perhaps those other resources are more expensive today, but that they will become less expensive in the future.  You might choose to cite the decrease in the cost of silicon PV panels as evidence.  I would then counter with the fact that solar is intermittent.  It produces about six hours per day on average, and then only on sunny days.  

(That's to say nothing of the massive fossil fuel inputs used to create the solar panels, especially in the production of the silver they require.  See [this SciAm article](http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/renewable-energys-hidden-costs/) for a shocking illustration of CO2 emissions per kWh from various energy sources, which is a rough a proxy of energy inputs.)

So in order for solar to become anything more than a bit player in the energy world, it will require backup or storage.  Currently, that backup is in the form of natural gas, the same fossil fuel that backs up wind.  Cost estimates for "firming" intermittent power sources like solar have been performed, and [they don't bode well for a renewable energy future](https://theconversation.com/counting-the-hidden-costs-of-energy-12710).

So what about your point about the finite nature of fossil fuels?  I happen to agree, very strongly in fact.  Of those who comment here, I would bet that I would set peak production for oil, gas, and coal earlier in time than anyone else.

Does that mean that I espouse Richard Heinberg's view that we must necessarily downsize the economy?  No.  (In fact, I think that stance is immoral, given state of energy poverty a few billion people still experience.)  There's another piece of the puzzle that those who believe in peak fossil fuels yet recognize how insufficient renewables are to the task don't often talk about.

housing.comment:
I do believe we can prevent climate change or at least reduce the impact it has. Think about it this way, if you are about five seconds from a brick wall in a car traveling 100 MPH, you'd still hit the breaks to try to slow it a little bit instead of keeping your foot on the gas.  Climate change is happening and we can at least take our foot off of the gas by reducing the amount of carbon we are producing as much as possible.  We can also metaphorically hit the break by coming up with ways to remove the existing green house gases from the atmosphere. Also, if the worst comes to worst, there are plenty of geo-engineering plans we could try to reverse climate change.  We are a global civilization that caused climate change without even trying, if we dedicate even a fraction of ourselves to fighting it, we can definitely do it. 

Your comparisons with other natural events are sort of pointless, but yes, we know how to stop an ice age; no, I don't think we can stop a volcanic eruption; I believe there is actually a growing amount of theory on how to stop hurricanes (but its never been tested); and no, but we can influence El Ninos.  The thing is, climate change is different from all of those this. We know what's causing it and how to combat it.  Even if we can't stop it completely, we can at least reduce the speed and severity with which it hits so humanity has more time to adapt to whatever changes may happen.

Energy, we do have nuclear fission as a back up, with the slight possibility of fusion at some point.  Also we do have solar power that works while its cloudy and we do know the places that almost constant wind happens.  Also, we are developing better and better batteries as the days go on so we can store energy for the times of less production. I believe one of the most promising battery technologies was a liquid metal battery that is made from very common elements and can store massive amounts of energy (its still in development though, last I heard).  There is also tidal energy, and also there are plenty of ways we are figuring out to more efficiently transmit energy so that large scale shortages of energy in one area can be supplemented by other areas power generation or stored energy.

I don't see how it is risky, at least in the US, our energy infrastructure already  needs a massive overhall and many cleaner energy options can be easily hooked into the grid, especially nuclear, and than other options once battery technology is sufficiently advanced (which seems to be rather soon).

It's not a conventional payment plan, but since I have net metering, I can always be sure my panel payment + electric bill is less than my electric bill would have been. So, if all goes according to Hoyle, 30 years of slightly cheaper payments then free power after that.

housing.comment:
If you own a home and have good credit, get a loan, and purchase the system.  Your savings will be easily double compared to a lease or PPA.

Here's how it would work.  Lets say you purchase a 4KW system.  Initial purchase price would probably be somewhere around $18,000 depending on what state you're in. You get a loan for $18,000 and ask bank to let you re-amortize for free one time.  You would get 30% ($5,400) of that back in the form of a tax refund.  You apply that $5,400 to the loan and re-amortize it.  So now you have a loan of $12,600, lets say for 15 years at 6%.  That would be about $106/month.

You might be saying, well that doesn't save me much right now.  However, that $106/month is fixed for 15 years.  Price of energy will increase every year, so even though you might not be saving much now, your savings will increase a bit every year.  Also, at the end of 15 years, the loan is paid off and then you get all the electricity from the panels at no cost for the remaining life of the system.

On top of that, when you purchase solar outright, the system adds equity to your house.  Figure you'll get at least half of the purchase price of the solar panels back when you sell your house.  So really you didn't pay $12,600, you only paid $6,300 for the system, which means even though you were paying $106/month, your effective net cost was really only $53/month. The other $53 was essentially a long term investment that will be paid back when you sell your home. 

Lease/PPA does not add equity to your house, and could end up being a liability.

housing.comment:
Let's go back to the basics for a bit. Since you are connected to the grid already, you only need batteries in your solar system if you need backup when the grid goes down. Most grid-tied solar systems do not have batteries, they have the solar panels, racking, and a grid-tied inverter connected to their main breaker box. The pros of this setup is 1) simple 2) inexpensive and depending on where you are, can be a quick ROI. 3) you can only make some of your power, and buy the rest from the grid, same as usual, or sell back any extra, creating a credit to use later when needed. The con is 1) when the grid goes down, even during a sunny day, so does your solar system, due to safety rules. 

If you do need battery backup, then you would have a hybrid a.k.a.  grid-tied battery backup solar system. With this, your inverter is connected to both the grid and a battery bank. You would determine what your critical loads are, those that have to be powered when the grid goes out, like a fridge, well pump, furnace fan, etc, and move the circuits to a new critical loads breaker box. You then size the battery bank to power them, not your whole house. Pros: you still don't need to make all of your power, when the grid is up, you still buy and sell as needed Con: more complex and expensive than straight grid-tied. 

Both of those options have  pure sine wave inverter, which is likely cleaner power than what you get from the grid, and therefore will not harm your electronics. Cheaper modified inverters may cause problems with delicate equipment.

housing.comment:
It probably won't happen. We'll see more utilities banning solar or reducing net metering which will be their undoing as people go off-grid. 

People like to hate on utility companies but it's rarely the occasion when they actually listen to their complaints.

Electricity in many places of the developed world functions as a regulated monopoly. The infrastructure required to power homes in the first place was expensive, and once it was in place, there'd be little incentive to add a competing transmission line or distribution network. For this same reason, once in place, people could be potentially be overcharged for what became a basic necessity. 

What ended up happening is that the government made deals with utilities where the utility would be granted an exclusive contract on an area, make an investment on infrastructure, and get a specific return on their investment. They wouldn't be allowed to charge whatever they wanted as the market could allow them to ("pay me 10x as much or lose power"), but in exchange they would have a predictable and long term return on their investment.

Then solar comes in and breaks this arrangement. Suddenly utility companies are being forced to pay market prices for power bought from their clients. They don't have the predictable revenue. They invested billions in infrastructure that may not be even needed in the future. They spent years limiting their sales prices to the agreed-upon pricing, but now have no upside.

Solar will probably never be backed by utilities for this reason. It's the technology that allows them to be irrelevant. Any accommodation will probably come from government regulation.

housing.comment:
I had the same questions, and this comes up fairly regularly on the forum, since it seems so cosmically unfair to sit in a powerless home with $50K of useless solar panels because, somehow, the grid doesn't provide power it seems you don't need :)

Here is my very rough understanding of the problem:

 * The grid tie serves as a load leveler for your solar production
 * When you produce more than you consume, the extra is dumped onto the grid where your neighbors suck it up
   * If this didn't happen, you'd blow your fuses with over-voltage, and if you wired around the fuses, you blow out all your electronic devices with same
 * When you produce less than you consume, you draw from the grid
   * If you didn't do this, all your devices would receive less power than they are rated to run at: some would run slow, some would fail, and some might have real problems because some components kept operating and others did not

OK, now you are in zombie apocalypse, or just subject to CA laws and housing market (same thing really), so all you care about is making it work.  So how do you solve this problem?  Well, unfortunately you need two things you don't have:

 * A energy store, to shove excess energy when sunny, and draw power when dark -- i.e. a battery
 * A [bimodal inverter](http://www.news-archives.solarenergy-usa.com/2011/06/what-is-a-bimodal-system-and-how-does-it-work/).  

So, your first zombie idea is:

 * Let me take my car/flashlight battery and connect that to the inverter
    * this would work if your car/flashlight battery could be charged with your full solar array without exploding, or get the draw of your entire house without a chemical meltdown
 * The inverter itself must be designed to work with the battery, so it doesn't, for instance, cause it to catch on fire by overcharging it
 * So, in practice, you have to buy a big, expensive battery to manage voltage for a significant part of your house.
 * When you do so, you are disappointed to learn that you can't hook the entire house up to one battery, because if you did, the maximum draw would exceed the battery warranty in some case, the speed of the chemical reaction in worst
 * This means you either have power to only certain sockets in power outage, or you buy multiple large, expensive batteries

OK, now let's pretend you have McGyvered a gigantic zombie battery, why won't your present inverter work?

 You'll have to ask someone with more knowledge than I've bothered to learn, but from my hazily remembered college physics and some half-scanned solar posts, here's why I believe a "normal" (i.e. cheaper to build) inverter can't be connected to battery: a bimodal (expensive) inverter has the ability to direct voltage from two sinks/sources (grid, battery), and when using battery, to limit the allowed power to what your battery can support (not having this 2nd part right can cause battery fires).

What I think normal inverters do is much simpler electronically, but more complicated to explain.  If you think of voltage as something like water pressure, a normal inverter basically uses the grid like a pipe connected to the water system:

 * when you magically produce water and push it into your pipe (panels->voltage), you run water away from your house due only to pressure (voltage), not requiring any smart valve or anything
 * When you open up a tap in house (close electrical circuit), you drain water from the system, again not requiring anything other than giving the water somewhere lower pressure to go

This only works because the grid is so much bigger than you, that you really can't effect its voltage (pressure) with your puny demand, much like you can't normally keep the whole block from getting water just because you blow one pipe.  So, the grid is functionally equivalent to an infinite capacity battery, that can charge or discharge as fast as any normal-sized system can produce or consume, and the normal inverter expects this, and has no way to restrict flow in either direction.

So, to use your zombie battery with your normal inverter, you need to make a battery than can store all the energy you can produce or consume infinitely fast, which physics does not allow.

*(yes, this pissed me off too)*

housing.comment:
There is no upper limit on solar thermal in my opinion. The new particle receiver technology which uses sand to store heat instead of oils is going to kick ass on batteries or pumped hydro as stand-by and on-demand load for an otherwise PV and wind based global energy  system. 


https://www.solarpaces.org/particle-receiver-first-commercial-trial-2018/

For people off the grid though, DIY solar thermal is . . . well I won't go on and on about what I think about steam but I want to share a little more info with you since you say you're Australian and I want to give credit where credit is due. I learned about some of my first farm-scale solar thermal systems from Australia where a lot of great research has been done. 

I don't know if you're familiar with ORC technology but the gist of it is to use an alternative to steam in a turbine such as volatile organic solvents like pentane or other liquids with lower boiling points than water. Much progress was made with that in Australia and they tried to sell it in the States but nobody would buy. 

Then, a breakthrough happened about ten years ago. An Australian group who had done vacuum tube solar collector arrays with organic rankine cycle and also big steam got funding from Silicon Valley venture capital. They were called Terrajoule and they had some great ideas and their system worked as promised. 

They not only custom manufactured 60HP brand spanking new made in USA steam engines but also dropped the big tip on the solar community that people like me hadn't known until then. They explained about the use of something called a "steam accumulators" which they didn't invent but simply borrowed from good ol' steam technology that already existed. I later learned that this was an idea as old as the steam engine itself but I simply hadn't known about it. 

These guys were smooth though and their big advance in this area was to point out that commercial propane tanks could be re-fitted as steam accumulators. With that they had 24/7 60HP in a location like the California Central Valley. They were selling it to farmers with deep water wells running diesel generators at five bucks a gallon. 

Okay, great story --so what happened to these guys? Well, the price of oil came back down. The price of oil used to be super high in California especially and although Terrajoule needed almost a million dollars to install one of their systems when all was totaled there were buyers at one time who felt it still made sense because the sun would continue shining indefinitely so the up-front costs weren't so bad but such investors dried up and the company was sold off to become a subsidiary of Air Liquide.

So the point of that long story is just to say that there is some very low hanging fruit out there and others have shown the way that this can be done practically. They spent too much money but it doesn't have to be that way. 

I ask you and I ask the guys I buy those tubes from in China why there are no decently priced 60HP steam engines coming out of China or India? That's what I'm looking out for. I actually started making my own out of a diesel truck cylinder out of frustration. 

Keep your eye on "slewing gear" at Alibaba. They're the big gears used in excavators and they are also quite useful for controlling large solar arrays. I suspect there will be turn-key kits coming out eventually with motors, controllers, sensors, mirrors etc. I have seen some on Alibaba already but the details weren't clear to me. 

Another tip on big gears for controlling an array of mirrors is to use fabric, some wire and resin and build up layers that you then bake together to make a massive and tough giant gear. 

I'd emphasize this point once again though that the lack of cheap steam engines is really quite shocking if energy is indeed such an important topic. I mean clearly we can directly make steam from the sun and we can even store steam too using off-the-shelf steel tanks so now if we had a way to conveniently turn it to mechanical energy or electricity that would be real nice for those people who do have a few acres of land on which to operate a small generation facility and indeed maybe even sell a bit to the neighbors or have enough extra to build a rental and offer free utilities or something of that nature.

housing.comment:
OK, have had system mostly working for about 2 weeks.  I posted a rainy day with L2 charging before, here is some more detail:

 * I have net metering, with overproduction becoming non-expiring credits that can only be used to offset later underproduction
 * In my state, I believe I will need to overproduce rest of year to heat home in winter, even though I have a geothermal heat pump
 * Week-long pic on right just bragging rights photo showing I'm so far running entire house + car and overproducing!
 * Day chart on left is of more interest I think:
   * Baseload varies between 300-500 watts
   * small periodic upticks that go 1 or 2 KW are geothermal heat pump, with two speed fan (some could also be due to water heater heat pump)
   * Just before noon, I start the washer, and I can't even see it on graph
  * Gigantic peaks around 1:30 & 4 are running the dryer (shirts followed by whites), 2nd peak had the geo pump running too
  * Final peak is me plugging in my Honda clarity to an L2 charger, with battery probably 3/4 full: its same height as dryer, probably because I have the type of L2 charger that plugs into a dryer socket :)

Anyway, I found the contrast quite interesting.  When I get my kill-a-watt meter back, want to try to figure out if dryer (ran occasionally) uses more/less energy than fridge (runs constantly, and my guess is quite a bit of my base load).

I installed the geo and solar at same time, so don't yet know whether I'll produce enough credits to get through winter.  Probably won't buy higher efficiency units until I see that, since the payback period is infinity if I'm producing all the power I'm using already . . .

housing.comment:
Just signed a contract at $37,800 so the numbers are fairly close if you would like them.

The tax credit will refund me $9828 of that at 26% this year, when your panels were installed it was probably larger at a 30% tax credit.  After the credit, my net cost for the system is $27,972.

It will offset $200 worth of my power bill monthly, or $2,400 per year.  Just on that math alone, in a worst case scenario I am breakeven at 11.6 years.  However power doesn’t tend to stay the same cost, in fact they are currently talking about raising rates 3% per year for the next decade.  So that $200 bill it will offset would be a $269 bill 10 years from now or $3,228 annually while my power rates are locked in and on my roof.  So my breakeven point at that math will be between 8.6 yrs and 11.6 years.  Let’s say they have paid for themselves at year 10 then.  They are fully warrantied for 25 and it’s not like they stop producing power on that 25th year, that’s simply the warranty period.  My power bill on that 25th year with 3% rate increases would have been $419 monthly.  The solar panels would have been generating me free cash flow for 15 years at that point, over 50k on the low end.  

Now, personally I built some energy efficiency upgrades into my overall plan.  If I can take 15% off of my average usage then I built my system’s size to offset about 10,000 miles of range on an Electric Vehicle annually as well.  Not paying for gasoline brings my breakeven point significantly closer and generates more cash flow in savings once they have paid themselves off.

With SREC’s coming to Virginia soon as well, that could play another role in pulling back that breakeven point.  

Hope that helped!

housing.comment:
That's why you separate energy charges from delivery charges.  Customers pay for (or are credited for) their net energy consumption (production), but they also pay a fixed charge and pay an extra delivery fee whenever they pull power from the grid.  My fixed charge is $20/month and my delivery charge is about $0.06 / kWh, so I pay $0.13 / kWh for power I take from the grid and get credited at $0.07 / kWh for power that I upload to the grid.  Exports bring my bill close to 0 in the summer, and I pay about $150 / month when my solar production drops by 85% in the winter.  That is fair to everyone, still results in a positive ROI for rooftop solar, and still provides an incentive to install storage later when battery prices fall.

Rooftop solar may not achieve ideal production numbers, but rooftops are otherwise wasted space that can and should be utilized for something productive.  The same goes for parking lots.  Utility scale solar will be needed too, but that should not exclude distributed generation.

housing.comment:
I also think I better understand your perspective now.

>The problem however is that we have zero influence in all of these. The closest we can do to influence these is picking what party to vote on.

I understand what you're saying, and I agree that the solutions I presented are not "individual choices," in the strictest sense, but they are the result of many "individual choices." Someone needs to run for public office, someone needs to educate the public, someone needs to work in the lab, someone needs to install solar panels, someone apparently us, need to try to convince people on the internet there is a problem worth solving; these aren't lifestyle choices (as defined by that study), but they can be impactful choices that go beyond how you simply choose to exist at home. Population growth is also not "an individual choice," it's a collective that results from the same summation of individual choices, which is why I don't see decarbonization as any less or more "individual" as population growth. 

You can't, by sheer force of will, *make* population growth slow, so you advocate for it. I can't *make* decarbonization happen either, so I advocate for it, and yes vote for it. That is all I am saying.

housing.comment:
You are basically SOL, but you are probably saving with the Sunrun system.  The only thing you can do to reduce your electricity costs is reduce your overall electricty use, in particular during peak times if you're on TOU.  This will reduce the NET bill you get from the utility, which means your overall electricity cost goes down.  You cannot reduce the Sunrun bill, it's effectively a fixed cost (depends on if it's a fixed lease, fixed ppa, or variable ppa).

The solar in a likelihood is saving you overall on electricty costs (maybe ~25% but really depends on factors) but if your expectation is "I have solar shouldn't electricity/utiliy be near zero", that's only if your solar production nearly matches your use over the year.  Important that the best months tend to be March-June with little to no utility bill, whereas all other you'll often have a utility bill, especially July to Septembe with AC use, or winter if you happen to have electric heat or water heater

The primary benefit of a Lease/PPA is not having to pay many thousands cash up front to get solar, but you will  can save some money. The Sunrun Lease or PPA is a set amount you're paying which typically less than if you didn't have solar.  Like if the utility charges $0.20/kWh, the energy from Sunrun is at Like $0.15/kWh. It's not a massive amount, but it's something.

The main way these can bad is if the Sunrun rate goes above the utility rate if you have an escalator that outpaces the utility increases.

housing.comment:
> Battery storage on the other hand requires the right economic incentives. 

Batteries (and solar panels to charge them) provide power when the power company has an outage.  It isn't all about the economics.  I understand a large percentage of people who install solar have this laser focus on trying to save money and ignore every other part of the decision, but it isn't all of us.

> Rooftop solar panels will pay for themselves in 7-10 years

I think that is wildly optimistic.  I would love to see the statistics on repairs and associated repair costs over that 7 - 10 year time.  Sure, if there are absolutely zero roof repairs (requiring extra work to remove the panels then replace them afterwards), and zero solar panel issues, and zero micro-inverter failures, and no circuit board failures in the internet gateways, **MAYBE** it breaks even in 7 - 10 years.  But a couple of repairs and that 7 - 10 years stretches out.

Finally (and this is the killer), most people don't realize if they took that same identical money and invested in an indexed mutual fund like VTSAX it would return 10% a year in the same 7 - 10 years.  Instead of buying $20,000 worth of solar panels, invest the money and it will be $40,000 in 7 years.  So the solar panels ACTUALLY cost $40,000 ($20,000 up front plus $20,000 in opportunity cost).  I used the interest calculator on this page: https://www.nerdwallet.com/calculator/compound-interest-calculator  That makes the payback period more like 14 - 20 years.  And at that point you would want to install an all new system anyway.

Solar panels don't make any economic sense for most individuals (like you mention, they do make sense for the industrial power companies).  Yet, knowing this, I installed solar (and batteries).  I've lived in three different states, and the power grid has failed me all the time in all three states.  The cheaper way to go is a natural gas generator, but it's stinky and uses fossil fuels, and then I have to worry about it possibly not starting up after a year of not being used.  If I use the solar panels and batteries **EVERY DAY** then they will most likely work just fine during a 4 day power outage.

Along the way, because of the economic savings (however large or small) the whole backup power system doesn't cost as much as the list price of the panels and batteries.  Heck, I'd be THRILLED if they all broke even financially in 10 years, because that means I installed an entire backup power system **FOR FREE**.  But I'm perfectly happy with it only costing me net $5,000 over 10 years also.  That comes to $1.37 per day (net) for a backup power system, which is the main goal of installing solar and batteries for me.

food.comment:
I disagree. You see, when people start saying something they aren't, they're not keeping it to themselves and they start confusing everyone else around them on what being a vegan means. If more and more people think veganism is "just a diet", well, you might be expected to accept animal exploitation derived gifts or offers.

Also, I'd hate for things to be labeled "vegan" but possibly be animal tested, to which I have to look further and contact the company to see if something is tested on animals. When I see the vegan lablel. I expect NO ANIMAL INGREDIENTS OR TESTING.

Once meanings and labels get diminished it just gets confusing for everyone....hence why there are vegetarians who eat fish, and worse, chicken. I do NOT want to see that happen to veganism, which is why I fight passionately to protect such a label and it's inner meaning, the same as I try inspire meat eaters to consider the animals, the health, or the environment, and give up meat.

food.comment:
Chimps are primarily frugivorous, which means that they eat mostly fruit.  About 95% of their diet, I think.  The evidence that human physiology is compatible with frugivory is pretty strong.  

You know how people say that humans are supposed to eat meat because our digestive systems are shorter than other vegetarian primates?  Well, long digestive systems are only really good for eating tough woody plants, like twigs and fibrous, mature leaves.  But if you have a short digestive system, you can happily eat fruit all day long.

food.comment:
Humans are the only animal capable of ethics, logic ... higher reasoning in general. We use it every day in some way. You haven't killed anyone today, or stolen something, or kicked an animal for no reason, have you? You have the opportunity to any of those things on any given day, yet most of us find all of those actions quite unpalatable and would probably agree doing any of those things is unethical. We made up what is or isn't ethical, but we have good reasons for deciding where that line is. One might say we've used logic to arrive there.

In this world, we can affect other living animals -- people and other animals. Animals have a lot of the same basic abilities or senses as people -- they have pain receptors, they can feel a number of emotions, and they have a drive to stay alive. What differs from other animals and humans is that in general their cerebral cortexes are not nearly as developed as ours. The cerebral cortex has a number of functions in humans, and is largely what is responsible for all the extra thinking that we can do that animals can't -- why we can have ethics, think logically, think about "others" and "self", etc. The cerebral cortex also gives us conscious control over ourselves, including our emotions so that say, if we feel angry, we can think about this anger and then decide how to actually feel and act. Animals don't have this ability for the most part, and so arguably feel emotions much more intensely than we do.

This is one reason why it seems so cruel to use them and mistreat them. Keeping cows locked up in concrete and cramped finishing lots, pigs who are confined to cages only big enough for them to stand or lie down and not turn around have to deal with all the frustration and anxiety they feel from being there every day. Then, many of them have their babies taken away from them, which they do feel a loss for. Animals produce oxytocin the same as humans when giving birth, and they bond with their young. It is heartbreaking for them to be separated from their babies, and vice versa for the babies from the mothers.

Animals also are fearful before death. When cows or pigs are crammed together and a guy starts shooting them in the head with pneumatic guns, the ones who haven't been shot yet can see what is happening, and they feel that fear. Maybe they don't know they're about to die, but they're freaked out about what's happening. If they're lucky, they get hung on the hooks upside down and have their throats cut when they're knocked out, but we know this doesn't happen for all of them, and so some of them hang there and bleed to death while still alive, and that is a horrible way to die, and they do feel it.

Now, of course, that is all how factory farms work, and perhaps you already agree that all those things are egregious. Perhaps on your farm you make sure every animal is unconscious before it is killed and it lives a very stress-free and good life up to that point. The rest of the vegan argument against raising and killing animals is more philosophical than it is about animal welfare.

We just believe that, if given the choice between having its life ended prematurely or living to old age, animals would choose the latter, much like humans. Alive things generally don’t wish to die if they’re otherwise in good health. We believe that, like people, animals should be free to live their lives and generally be autonomous so long as it doesn't endanger others (same applies to humans). We find it hypocritical to keep dogs or cats for enjoyment and that it is generally thought of to be unthinkable to kill and eat one while simultaneously being perfectly fine with killing and eating other animals, many of them mammals with just as much neurologic sophistication as dogs and cats.

You said
>That humans think they are somehow endowed with some special consciousness that lifts us above bacteria, invertebrates, plants, and animals is poor logic.

But humans *are* special for the reasons I listed above -- that we have neurology other animals don't, and this gives us the ability to think and reason. Citing how anything happens in nature is what is poor logic. We are animals, yes, so we are not separate from nature in that way. But we haven't done everything "natural" for at least 10,000 years (when we started farming) and probably for even longer (I have no idea when we started making tools and talking, but it was much longer than 10,000 years ago).

What vegans are saying is that we can think and reason, and animals can't. Animals kill each other, yes, but humans don't have to. We can make a decision about every aspect of our lives, so let's try to make good decisions. Regarding what to eat -- does it seem like a good or right thing to do to kill an animal who undoubtedly would have liked to live, and possibly suffered at least some fear and anxiety right before it died (if it's lucky) just to eat?

The answer to that depends on your deeper philosophy.
Do you value non-human life? Under what circumstances? Is all non-human life equivalent? If not, how do you order things? Why do you order it that way? Does non-human life have any right to its own life? If not -- why?

Do we need to eat animals in today's world? The fact that all of us vegans exist would seem to indicate the answer to this one.

Are there bigger reasons beyond your own taste preferences for eating meat or not? Does eating meat versus not eating meat affect the environment, and if so, how? Is eating meat a good use of resources, and does this matter to you? (Generally, eating higher up on a food chain means more energy is wasted. Farm animals who aren’t solely pastured eat grains that humans could have eaten. They eat more calories in grains than they produce. Thus, it is a waste of food energy to make meat in the first place. Same with water.)

I think you know the vegans answer to these questions, but if not, I’d be happy to enlighten you. These questions were somewhat rhetorical, but perhaps it would be a good exercise for you to answer them to see where you stand. Vegans generally think that animals do have a right to their own lives, and therefore it is unethical to kill them. Again, we generally don’t kill and eat dogs, and this seems very arbitrary – logically inconsistent. Most people know pigs are just as smart as dogs. But we don’t believe an animal’s intelligence has anything to do with their right to life. Just as another human’s life, or if you like a dog’s or cat’s life, is not ours to take, neither is it ours to take a cow’s, pig’s, chicken’s, etc’s life.

I avoid it like I would anything non-vegan, for the most part. If someone buys something with it in for me because it's vegan I might eat it just to avoid wasting food, but I otherwise avoid it on principle even if it's free. One thing you need to be aware of is palm oil can be hidden under different names so it's not always as simple as looking for 'palm oil' in the ingredients list. 


http://www.treehugger.com/sustainable-agriculture/25-sneaky-names-palm-oil.html

I've heard the argument that if we don't buy products that use sustainable palm oil then manufacturers wouldn't have any incentive to source sustainable palm oil. The same logic works with so-called 'humane' animal products, so I decided to avoid it altogether. 

This link might help as far as alternatives for baking go http://www.veganbaking.net/articles/guides/best-oils-for-vegan-baking

food.comment:
None of us are under any obligations to try to spread veganism, but it's clearly a good thing to do.

I understand that for some people, in some situations, talking about veganism can cause social discomfort. Personally I can't imagine having to deal with what you say you've experienced, and I feel very lucky for that (it could just be that Canadians keep impolite thoughts to themselves most of the time). However, whatever social discomfort I might occasionally experience, is nothing compared to what animals go through. It's really important to keep that in mind and not forget why we are doing this (for the animals). For me, the risk of having an unpleasant encounter with someone is far less than the reward of the possibility that they might consider going vegan.

food.comment:
Okay. Any doctor trying to disrupt a patient’s diet is not a good doctor.

I’m in med school in India, where vegetarianism is pretty common, and although vegetarians here  are more likely than meat-eaters to have some deficiencies, the number one thing we are taught is to ask the patient what their normal diet is and if they have any religious or other beliefs that restrict the intake of certain foods. We are taught to recommend diets based only on what the patient is willing to consume- telling a vegetarian patient to eat meat is the best way to make sure they will not adhere to your diet plan, and end up even sicker than before.

Doctors should be trying to recommend diets which cause the least amount of change in your existing food habits, and require the least amount of effort to accommodate into your lifestyle. Only then will a patient actually stick to the diet and end up with good results. That’s literally rule number 1. 

Only if this fails, we are taught to move on to other options or simply prescribe supplements if the patient is unable to or unwilling to make those changes. 

It’s surprising to me that doctors in developed countries with better medical education systems aren’t taught this very basic thing. Poor patient adherence is the number one cause of treatment failure and diet failure, and doctors should be trying to prevent that at all costs.

food.comment:
It's all well and good that your diet works for you, but meat consumption and factory farmed (as well as organically farmed meat) are responsible for over half of all global greenhouse gas emissions. Elevated levels of greenhouse gases lead to conditions such as COPD, asthma, pneumonia. Because it requires such a large amount of land to graze these animals (more than a third of US land is used for animal pastures) it leads to deforestation in rainforests as well as having both a positive and negative effect on the quality of soil in the places where livestock are raised. Around 30% of forests around the world have been completely cleared for agriculture usage, and another 20% near total degradation, and this number increases as the demand for meat and animal agriculture products increases. The water needed to raise these livestock is just not sustainable in the long term, meaning the destruction of fresh water sources, as well as the depletion of fish species, bringing the ecosystems that surround these places closer to extinction. Countries also see the actual quality of their water decrease as they dispose of animal product wastage. There are many other negatives that come from the factory farming of meat that a switch to plant based diets could solve, such as antibiotic resistence, but that's not the point. The point is that there needs to be a government mandated switch to plant based diets. You're never going to convince someone to switch from meat to plants because it is simply a personal pleasure the majority of us are unwilling to give up, and it's not possible for one person going vegan to make much of a difference. 

Unfortunately, because meat is too tasty and too much of a sticking point for many people, the only way we can rectify some of the damage meat based agriculture does to the planet is to at least mitigate it somewhat with mandates and education. If you need meat to survive, then fine, but the majority of people don't and can be just as healthy and natural on a plant based diet.

food.comment:
I shoot for 1g per kg body mass, the recommendation is .75g per Kg, but doing 1g makes the math easy and covers for low protein days. I'm 120lbs, 54kg, so I shoot for 54g, my SO is 160lbs, 72kg, so he drinks a protein shake in the morning to get some extra. 54g of protein is pretty easy to get in a day without processed foods. I eat a lot of oats, bread, ancient grain blends, tofu, lentils, beans, nuts. I also eat high protein snacks like roasted chickpeas, hummus, peanut butter and nutritional yeast sprinkled on savory stuff. 

Yesterday's dinner was homemade rolls and a large bowl of baked potato soup with nooch and tvp bacon bits on top. Just did a quick calculation and the soup was 27.5g protein and the rolls were about 3g each and I ate 4 of them. I got nearly 40g of protein just from dinner last night. Nooch and tvp aren't exactly whole foods, but they're one ingredient so 🤷🏼

food.comment:
> Gonna go out on a limb and say amputees are a considerably smaller demographic than people who don't fall into the category of "skinny". But yeah, some amputees probably feel excluded and marginalized in plenty of other ways too. 

Sure. But excluding amputees doesn't imply any sort of "amputee shaming" or amputee hate. Being an amputee isn't a good thing though: very few people would willingly become an amputee if they had a choice. It's not considered aesthetic by most either. 

Unless an advertising campaign was specifically targeted toward amputees, there wouldn't be a benefit to displaying them.

In this case, it would be kind of like an organization dedicated to preventing workplace injury putting out a pamphlet on how to avoid injury featuring a bunch of smiling quadriplegics (who didn't lose their limbs in a workplace accident, of course): it just would have a counterproductive effect. Likewise featuring obese vegans in vegan propaganda.

> Diversity is awesome. I'd love to see vegan propaganda with people in wheelchairs, people with all sorts of ethnic backgrounds, various genders, body types, the whole deal.

Maybe I'm weird, but I really don't give a damn if I see someone like me in advertising. If I see someone in advertising that accentuates traits that I consider negative, that's also going to make me perceive the advertising more negatively. If I was fat, I wouldn't really be happy about it: it wouldn't somehow make me see fat people in advertising as appealing and "like me".

> If we're following a lifestyle that's about compassion, why not take extra steps to be inclusive and welcoming? 

By all means. But there's a major difference between that and accusing others of "body shaming".
